The '''Association of Art Historians''' ('''AAH''') promotes the professional practice and public understanding of [[art history]].<ref name=aah>[http://www.aah.org.uk/page/2757 About AAH.] Association of Art Historians, 2015. Retrieved 5 February 2015.</ref> It was formed in 1974, is based in [[London]], [[England]], and is a [[registered charity]] (No. 1154066).<ref name="cc" />
==Membership== Individual membership is open to anyone with a professional commitment to and interest in art history and visual culture. Institutional membership is also available.<ref name="aah" />
Members can get involved in the following interest groups:
*Freelance and independents *Higher and further education *Schools *Students *Museums & exhibitions.
==Governance and financial== The Association is governed by a Board of Trustees. For the year ended 31 December 2010, the AAH had a gross income of £396,818 and expenditure of £359,507 according to accounts filed with the [[Charity Commission]].<ref name="cc">[http://www.charity-commission.gov.uk/Showcharity/RegisterOfCharities/CharityWithoutPartB.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=282579&SubsidiaryNumber=0 Association of Art Historians], [[Charity Commission for England and Wales|The Charity Commission]], UK, 2011. Retrieved 21 July 2011.</ref>
==Publications== There is a quarterly newsletter, the ''Bulletin'', and a scholarly journal ''[[Art History (journal)|Art History]]'' published five times a year in association with [[Wiley-Blackwell]], which is peer-reviewed.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://art-history.concordia.ca/rvacanada/associations.html | title=Art History Associations | publisher=[[Concordia University]] | location=Canada | accessdate=4 November 2012 }}</ref>
==Events== Regular events take place, often organised by volunteers from the various member interest groups, together with an annual conference.
==Affiliations== The AAH is affiliated with the US [[College Art Association]] (CAA) and supports the [[Comité International d'Histoire de l'Art]] (CIHA).<ref name="aah" />

{{ref improve|date=January 2015}} [[File:An-actress-at-her-toilet-or-miss-brazen-just-breecht-john-colley.jpg|300px|thumb|1779 John Colley Playbill of an actress dressing in breeches]] {{Crossdressing|history}} A '''breeches role''' (also '''pants role''' or '''trouser role''', ''[[Travesti (theatre)|travesti]]'' or "Hosenrolle") is a role in which an actress appears in male clothing. [[Breeches]] ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|r|ɪ|tʃ|ᵻ|z}}, also "britches"), tight-fitting knee-length pants, were the standard male garment at the time breeches roles were introduced.
In opera it also refers to any male character that is sung and acted by a female singer. Most often the character is an adolescent or a very young man, sung by a [[mezzo-soprano]] or [[contralto]].<ref name="Grove">Budden J. Breeches part. In: ''The New Grove Dictionary of Opera.'' Macmillan, London and New York, 1997.</ref> The operatic concept assumes that the character is male, and the audience accepts him as such, even knowing that the actor is not. Cross-dressing female characters (e.g., Leonore in ''[[Fidelio]]'' or Gilda in Act III of ''[[Rigoletto]]'') are not considered breeches roles. The most frequently performed breeches roles are Cherubino (''[[The Marriage of Figaro]]''), Octavian (''[[Der Rosenkavalier]])'', Hansel (''[[Hansel und Gretel (opera)|Hansel und Gretel]]'') and Orpheus (''[[Orfeo ed Euridice|Orpheus and Euridice]]''), though the latter was originally written for a male singer, first a [[castrato]] and later, in the revised French version, an [[haute-contre]].
Because non-musical stage plays generally have no requirements for vocal range, they do not usually contain breeches roles in the same sense as opera. Some plays do have male roles that were written for adult female actors, and (for other practical reasons) are usually played by women (e.g., ''[[Peter and Wendy|Peter Pan]]''); these could be considered modern-era breeches roles. However, in most cases, the choice of a female actor to play a male character is made at the production level; [[Hamlet#Hamlet as a character|Hamlet]] is not a breeches role, but [[Sarah Bernhardt]] once played Hamlet ''as'' a breeches role. When a play is spoken of as "containing" a breeches role, this ''does'' mean a role where a female character pretends to be a man and uses male clothing as a disguise.
== History == When the London theatres re-opened in 1660, the first professional actresses appeared on the public stage, replacing the boys in dresses of the [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]] era. To see real women speak the risqué dialogue of [[Restoration comedy]] and show off their bodies on stage was a great novelty, and soon the even greater sensation was introduced of women wearing male clothes on stage. Out of some 375 plays produced on the London stage between 1660 and 1700, it has been calculated that 89, nearly a quarter, contained one or more roles for actresses in male clothes (see Howe). Practically every Restoration actress appeared in trousers at some time, and breeches roles would even be inserted gratuitously in revivals of older plays.
Some critics, such as Jacqueline Pearson, have argued that these [[cross-dressing]] roles subvert conventional [[gender roles]] by allowing women to imitate the roistering and sexually aggressive behaviour of male Restoration [[Rake (character)|rakes]], but Elizabeth Howe has objected in a detailed study that the male disguise was "little more than yet another means of displaying the actress as a sexual object". The epilogue to [[Thomas Southerne]]'s ''Sir Anthony Love'' (1690) suggests that it does not much matter if the play is dull, as long as the audience can glimpse the legs of the famous "breeches" actress [[Susanna Verbruggen|Susanna Mountfort]] (also known as Susanna Verbruggen):
:You'll hear with Patience a dull Scene, to see, :In a contented lazy waggery, :The Female Mountford bare above the knee.
Katharine Eisaman Maus also argues that as well as revealing the female legs and buttocks, the breeches role frequently contained a revelation scene where the character not only unpins her hair but as often reveals a breast as well. This is evidenced in the portraits of many of these actresses of the Restoration.
Breeches roles remained an attraction on the British stage for centuries, but their fascination gradually declined as the difference in real-life male and female clothing became less extreme. They played a part in [[Victorian burlesque]] and are traditional for the [[principal boy]] in [[pantomime]].
== Opera == Historically, the list of roles that are considered to be breeches roles is constantly changing, depending on the tastes of the opera-going public. In early Italian opera, many leading operatic roles were assigned to a [[castrato]], a male castrated before puberty with a very strong and high voice. As the practice of castrating boy singers faded, composers created heroic male roles in the mezzo-soprano range, where singers such as [[Marietta Alboni]] and Rosamunda Pisaroni specialised in such roles.<ref name="Grove"/> (See ''[[Serse|Xerxes]]'' below.)
Currently, many castrato roles are being reclaimed by men. As the training and use of [[countertenor]]s becomes more common, there are more men with these very high voices to sing these roles.
Casting directors are left with choices such as whether to cast the young Prince Orlofsky in [[Johann Strauss II|Johann Strauss II's]] ''[[Die Fledermaus]]'' for a woman or man; both commonly sing the role. When played by a mezzo, the prince looks like a woman, but sounds like a boy. When played by a counter-tenor, he looks like a man, but sings like a woman. This disparity is made even clearer if, as in this case, there is also spoken dialogue.
The term ''Travesty'' (from the Italian ''travesti'', disguised) applies to any roles sung by the opposite sex.<ref>Budden J. Travesty. In: ''The New Grove Dictionary of Opera.'' Macmillan, London and New York, 1997.</ref>
A closely related term is a ''skirt role'', a female character to be played by a male singer, usually for comic or visual effect. These roles are often ugly stepsisters or very old women, and are not as common as trouser roles. As women were not allowed to sing on stage in the [[Papal States]] during the [[Baroque period]], many female operatic roles which premiered in those areas were originally written as skirt roles for [[castrato|castrati]] (e.g. ''Mandane'' and ''Semira'' in [[Leonardo Vinci]]'s [[Artaserse (Vinci)|Artaserse]]). Britten's Madwoman in ''[[Curlew River]]'' and the Cook in Prokofiev's ''[[The Love for Three Oranges]]'' are examples. The role of the witch in Humperdinck's ''[[Hänsel und Gretel (opera)|Hänsel und Gretel]]'', although written for a mezzo-soprano is now more regularly{{Citation needed|date=February 2013}} sung by a tenor, who sings the part an octave lower. In the same opera the "male" roles of Hänsel, the Sandman, and the Dewman are however meant to be sung by women.
Operas with '''breeches roles''' include:
* [[Thomas Adès|Adès]]'s ''[[The Tempest (opera)|The Tempest]]'': "Ariel" is sung by a soprano * [[Thomas Arne|Arne]]'s ''[[Artaxerxes (opera)|Artaxerxes]]'': "Arbaces" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * [[Mark Adamo|Adamo]]'s ''[[Little Women (opera)|Little Women]]'': "Friedrich Bhaer" may be sung by a mezzo-soprano. * [[Vincenzo Bellini|Bellini]]'s ''[[Bianca e Fernando]]'': "Viscardo" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * Bellini's ''[[Zaira (opera)|Zaira]]'': "Nerestano" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * Bellini's ''[[I Capuleti e i Montecchi]]'': "Romeo" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * [[Alban Berg|Berg]]'s ''[[Lulu (opera)|Lulu]]'': "Der Gymnasiast" (a Schoolboy) is sung by a contralto * [[Hector Berlioz|Berlioz]]'s ''[[Benvenuto Cellini (opera)|Benvenuto Cellini]]'': "Ascanio" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * Berlioz's ''[[Les Troyens]]'': "Ascanio" is sung by a soprano * [[Alfredo Catalani|Catalani]]'s ''[[La Wally]]'': "Walter" is sung by a soprano * [[Emmanuel Chabrier|Chabrier]]'s ''[[L'étoile (opera)|L'étoile]]'': "Lazuli" the peddler is sung by a soprano * Chabrier's ''[[Une éducation manquée]]'': "Gontran de Boismassif" is sung by a soprano * [[Marc-Antoine Charpentier|Charpentier]]'s ''[[David et Jonathas]]'': "Jonathas" is sung by a soprano; [[Witch of Endor|La Pythonisse]] is sung by a [[haute-contre]], which is a high-pitched male voice, similar to a Countertenor. * [[John Corigliano|Corigliano]]'s "[[The Ghosts of Versailles]]": "Cherubino" (a recreation of the same character from ''[[The Marriage of Figaro|Le nozze di Figaro]]'') is sung by a mezzo-soprano * [[Gaetano Donizetti|Donizetti]]'s ''[[Alahor in Granata]]'': "Muley-Hassem" is sung by a contralto * Donizetti's ''[[Anna Bolena]]'': "Smeton" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * Donizetti's ''[[Lucrezia Borgia (opera)|Lucrezia Borgia]]'': "Maffio Orsini" is sung by a contralto * [[Antonín Dvořák|Dvořák]]'s ''[[Rusalka (opera)|Rusalka]]'': "The Kitchen Boy" is sung by a soprano * [[Mikhail Glinka|Glinka]]'s ''[[A Life for the Tsar]]'': "Vanya" is sung by a contralto * Glinka's ''[[Ruslan and Lyudmila (opera)|Ruslan and Lyudmila]]'': "Ratmir" is sung by a contralto * [[Gluck]]'s ''[[Orfeo ed Euridice]]'': Originally written for a castrato, "Orfeo" is sung by a mezzo-soprano, contralto or counter-tenor * Gluck's ''[[Paride ed Elena]]'': Originally written for a castrato, "Paride" is sung by a soprano * [[Gounod]]'s ''[[Faust (opera)|Faust]]'': "Siebel" is sung by a contralto, a mezzo-soprano or a soprano * Gounod's ''[[Roméo et Juliette|Romeo and Juliet]]'': "Stefano" is sung by a soprano * [[Reynaldo Hahn|Hahn]]'s ''[[Mozart (comédie musicale)|Mozart]]'': The title is sung by a soprano * [[Händel]]'s ''[[Alcina]]'': "Ruggiero" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * Händel's ''[[Ariodante]]'': The role of "Ariodante" was premiered by a soprano-castrato and is performed today by a mezzo-soprano; "Lurcanio" was originally written for contralto, but later rewritten by Handel for tenor.<ref>Bärenreiter Kassel (BA 4079a) notes</ref> In modern performances it is generally left to the director to decide whether to use contralto (or countertenor) or a lyric tenor. * Händel's ''[[Giulio Cesare]]'': "Julius Caesar" was originally written for an alto-castrato and is today sung by a mezzo-soprano or countertenor; "Sesto" is sung by a soprano * Händel's ''[[Serse|Xerxes]]'': the title role "Xerxes", sung at its premiere by a [[castrato]], is currently sung by a mezzo-soprano or a countertenor * [[Joseph Haydn|Haydn]]'s ''[[La canterina]]'': The role of "Don Ettore" is sung by a soprano * [[Charles Lecocq|Lecocq]]'s ''[[Le petit duc]]'': the title role is sung by a soprano * [[Engelbert Humperdinck (composer)|Humperdinck]]'s ''[[Hänsel und Gretel (opera)|Hänsel und Gretel]]'': "Hänsel" is sung by a mezzo-soprano; The Sand-Man and The Dew-Man sung by sopranos; The Witch often sung by a tenor * [[Leoš Janáček|Janáček]]'s ''[[From the House of the Dead]]'': Aljeja, a young Tartar is sung by a mezzo-soprano * [[Jules Massenet|Massenet]]'s ''[[Cendrillon]]'': the role of "Le Prince Charmant" was written for a soprano (in some performances the role is taken by a tenor) * Massenet's ''[[Chérubin]]'': The title role is sung by a soprano * [[Giacomo Meyerbeer|Meyerbeer]]'s ''[[Les Huguenots]] '': "Urbain" the page is sung by a mezzo-soprano * [[Claudio Monteverdi|Monteverdi]]'s ''[[L'incoronazione di Poppea]]'': "Nero" is sung by a soprano (today the role is often sung by a male tenor or contratenor) * [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]]'s ''[[The Marriage of Figaro|Le nozze di Figaro]]'': "Cherubino" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * Mozart's ''[[La clemenza di Tito]] '': "Sesto" and "Annio" are sung by sopranos * Mozart's ''[[Idomeneo]]'': "Idamante" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * Mozart's ''[[Il re pastore]]'': "Aminta" was originally written for soprano-castrato, and in modern performances is sung by a lyric soprano * Mozart's ''[[Lucio Silla]]'': "Cecilio" and "Lucio Cinna" are sung by sopranos * Mozart's ''[[Ascanio in Alba]]'': "Ascanio" and "Fauno" are sung by sopranos * Mozart's ''[[Mitridate, re di Ponto]]'': "Farnace" is sung by a mezzo-soprano or contralto, and "Sifare" and "Arbate" are sung by sopranos. However, "Farnace" is commonly done by a countertenor. * Mozart's ''[[La finta giardiniera]]'': "Ramiro" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * [[Jacques Offenbach|Offenbach]]'s ''[[Mesdames de la Halle]]'': ''Croûte-au-pot'' (the kitchen boy) is sung by a soprano; ''Madame Poiretapée, Madame Madou, and Madame Beurrefondu'' are sung by a tenor and two baritones * Offenbach's ''[[Geneviève de Brabant]]'': "Drogan" the young baker is sung by a soprano * Offenbach's ''[[Daphnis et Chloé (Offenbach)|Daphnis et Chloé]]'': "Daphnis" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * Offenbach's ''[[Le pont des soupirs]]'': The page "Amoroso" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * Offenbach's ''[[Les bavards]]'': The young poet "Roland" is sung by a contralto * Offenbach's ''[[La belle Hélène]]'': "Oreste" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * Offenbach's ''[[Robinson Crusoé]]'': "Friday" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * Offenbach's ''[[Les brigands]]'': The farmer "Fragoletto" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * Offenbach's ''[[La jolie parfumeuse]]'': The young clerk "Bavolet" is sung by a soprano * Offenbach's ''[[Madame l'archiduc]]'': "Fortunato, captain of the archduke's dragoons" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * Offenbach's ''[[Le voyage dans la lune (operetta)|Le voyage dans la lune]]'': "Prince Caprice" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * Offenbach's ''[[The Tales of Hoffmann]]'': "Nicklausse" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * Offenbach's ''[[Orphée aux enfers]]'': "Cupidon" (Cupid) is sung by a soprano * [[Hans Pfitzner|Pfitzner]]'s ''[[Palestrina (opera)|Palestrina]]'': Ighino is sung by a soprano; Silla by a mezzo-sporano * [[Ravel]]'s ''[[L'enfant et les sortilèges]]'': the title role of The Boy is written for a mezzo-soprano; The Shepherd is sung by a mezzo-soprano * [[Gioachino Rossini|Rossini]]'s ''[[Tancredi]]'': "Tancredi" and "Roggiero" are sung by mezzo-sopranos or contraltos * Rossini's ''[[Bianca e Falliero]]'': "Falliero" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * Rossini's ''[[La donna del lago]]'': "Malcolm" is sung by a contralto * Rossini's ''[[Le comte Ory]] '': "Isolier" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * Rossini's ''[[Semiramide]]'': "Arsace" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * Rossini's ''[[Otello (Rossini)|Otello]]'': the title role was written for a tenor, but also was sung by mezzo-soprano [[Maria Malibran]] * Rossini's ''[[William Tell (opera)|Guillaume Tell]]'': Tell's son Jemmy is sung by a soprano * [[Gil Shohat]]'s ''[[The Child Dreams (opera)|The Child Dreams]]'': "The Child" is sung by a soprano; "The Crippled Youth" (i.e. The Poet) by a mezzo-soprano * [[Kaija Saariaho]]'s ''[[L'Amour de loin]]'': "The Pilgrim" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * [[Johann Strauss II]]'s ''[[Die Fledermaus]]'': "Prince Orlofsky" is sung by a mezzo-soprano (almost always) * [[Richard Strauss]]'s ''[[Salome (opera)|Salome]]'': "The Page of Herodias" is sung by a contralto * Richard Strauss's ''[[Ariadne auf Naxos]]'': "The Composer" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * Richard Strauss's ''[[Der Rosenkavalier]]'': "Octavian" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * [[Giuseppe Verdi|Verdi]]'s ''[[Un ballo in maschera]]'': "Oscar", Gustavus III's page, is sung by a soprano * Verdi's ''[[Don Carlos]]'': The page Thibault (Tebaldo) is sung by a soprano * [[Richard Wagner|Wagner]]'s ''[[Rienzi]]'': "Adriano" is sung by a mezzo-soprano * Wagner's ''[[Tannhäuser (opera)|Tannhäuser]]'': The Young Shepherd is sung by a soprano * Wagner's ''[[Parsifal]]'': Two novices in the all-male society of Knights of the Grail are sung by sopranos * Wagner's ''[[Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg]]'': Several [[apprentices]] are sung by women * [[Carl Maria von Weber|Weber]]'s ''[[Oberon (Weber)|Oberon]]'': "Puck" is sung by a mezzo-soprano

'''Chicano studies''' originated in the [[Chicano Movement]] of the late 1960s and 1970s.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|url = http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/latin_american_research_review/v040/40.2foster.html|title = Recent Chicana/O Cultural Criticism|last = Foster|first = David William|date = 2005|journal = Latin American Research Review|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 12 May 2015|volume = 40|issue = 2|pages = 166–177|subscription = yes}}</ref> Chicano studies concerns itself with the study of [[Chicano]]s, [[Latinos]], and [[Mexican Americans]],<ref>National Association for Chicana and Chicano Studies, http://www.naccs.org/naccs/About_NACCS_EN.asp?SnID=1529216044{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> drawing upon a variety of fields, including, but not limited to, [[history]], [[sociology]], [[the arts]], and [[Chicana]]/[[Chicano]] theory.
In many universities across the United States, Chicano Studies is linked with interdisciplinary ethnic studies and other [[Ethnic Studies]] fields such as [[Black Studies]], [[Asian American Studies]], and [[Native American Studies]]. Many students who have studied anthropology have also been involved in varying degrees in Chicano studies.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|url = http://eric.ed.gov/?id=ED438967|title = Chicano Drivers of Ideas in Anthropology across Space and Place: Pre-Postmodern Debts to Chicano Studies and Others|last = Velez-Ibanez|first = Carlos G.|date = 1998|journal = JSRI Occasional Paper No. 53 Latino Studies Series|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 12 May 2015}}</ref> Today most major universities in areas of high Chicano concentration have a formal Chicano studies department or interdisciplinary program.<ref name=":1" /> Providing classes in the ethnic studies area, like Chicano studies has been shown to help the "learning environment for students of color through limiting feelings of prejudice and experiences of discrimination in college."<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|url = http://muse.jhu.edu/cgi-bin/login.cgi|title = Counterspaces and Connections in College Transitions: First-Generation Latino Students' Perspectives on Chicano Studies|last = Nuñez|first = Anne-Marie|date = 2011|journal = Journal of College Student Development|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 12 May 2015|volume = 52|subscription = yes|issue = 6|pages = 639–655}}</ref>
==History== Many Chicano scholars agree that Chicano studies came about as a result of the Chicano student movements, whether they were in the form of protests, activism or just taking part in ''[[Chicano Movement|el movimiento]]''.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Chicano Studies: The Genesis of a Discipline|last = Soldatenko|first = Michael|publisher = University of Arizona Press|year = 2012|isbn = 9780816599530|location = Tucson, Arizona|pages = 12–37|chapter = The Genesis of Academic Chicano Studies, 1967-1970|url = http://muse.jhu.edu/books/9780816599530/9780816599530-6.pdf|access-date = 12 May 2015|format = PDF}}</ref> Chicano studies was seen as a way to advance Mexican American perspectives on culture, history and literature.<ref name=":3" /> The major push for universities and colleges to include Chicano studies came within the context of the African-American civil rights struggle.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url = http://eric.ed.gov/?id=ED273429|title = The Current Status and Future of Chicano Studies Programs: Are They Academically Sound?|date = April 1986|accessdate = 12 May 2015|website = ERIC|publisher = U.S. Department of Education|last = Rochin|first = Refugio I.|last2 = de la Torre|first2 = Adela}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url = http://eric.ed.gov/?id=ED114133|title = Administrative Reorganizational Needs in Chicano Studies at Cerritos College|date = 25 April 1975|accessdate = 12 May 2015|website = ERIC|publisher = U.S. Department of Education|last = Hinrichsen|first = Keith A.}}</ref> During this period, Mexican American educators demanded that colleges and universities address the pedagogical needs of Mexican American students.<ref name=":5" /> This was especially important because Mexican American student populations grew significantly in the 1960s.<ref name=":2" /> In addition, many young people and students were becoming very politically active and began to organize for political causes.<ref name=":2" /> A very prominent student organization that grew out of the civil rights movements of the '60s was the [[Mexican American Youth Organization]] (MAYO), which began to work towards educational reform.<ref name=":8">{{Cite book|title = The Making of Chicano Studies: In the Trenches of Academe|last = Acuna|first = Rodolfo|publisher = Rutgers University Press|year = 2011|isbn = 9780813550701|location = New Brunswick|pages = 36–58|chapter = From Student Power to Chicano Studies|url = http://muse.jhu.edu/books/9780813550701/9780813550701-10.pdf|access-date = 13 May 2015}}</ref> MAYO was very active in promoting student walkouts in [[Texas]] and [[California]] to highlight problems that Mexican American students faced.<ref name=":8" /> As students became more organized, they began to develop "experimental colleges" where informal classes on topics important to the Chicano movement were taught.<ref name=":8" />
Manuel H. Guerra, professor at the University of Southern California and chair of the [[Mexican American Political Association|Mexican American Political Association's]] (MAPA) Education Committee, reported in 1963 on "serious discriminatory policies and practices" at his university in relation to hiring Mexican Americans, especially considering that there had been an increase in the number of Mexican American students.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title = The Making of Chicano Studies: In the Trenches of Academe|last = Acuna|first = Rodolfo|publisher = Rutgers University Press|year = 2011|isbn = 9780813550015|location = New Brunswick|pages = 14–35|url = http://muse.jhu.edu/books/9780813550701/9780813550701-9.pdf|chapter = The Sixties and the Bean Count}}</ref> Serving Mexican American students without providing Mexican American faculty was considered a sort of colonialism and cultural assimilation.<ref name=":2" /> In addition, many Mexican American students were put at a disadvantage because speaking [[Spanish language|Spanish]] (even outside of class) was considered "degrading" or "un-American."<ref name=":8" /> Opportunities such as the Educational Opportunity Program (EOP) helped increase the number of minorities entering colleges and universities.<ref name=":8" /> Educators and students alike began to visualize "an academic program that could serve and transform the Mexican American community," a program that would become Chicano studies and which was built by and for Chicanos.<ref name=":11">{{Cite book|title = Chicano Studies: The Genesis of a Discipline|last = Soldatenko|first = Michael|publisher = University of Arizona Press|year = 2012|isbn = 9780816599530|location = Tucson, Arizona|pages = 38–66|chapter = Empirics and Chicano Studies: The Formation of Empirical Chicano Studies, 1970-1975|url = http://muse.jhu.edu/books/9780816599530/9780816599530-7.pdf|access-date = 14 May 2015}}</ref>
In 1967, anthropologist Octavio Romano along with graduate students at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] began to publish a Chicano studies journal called ''El Grito: A Journal of Contemporary Mexican-American Thought''.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=f5h&AN=76504493&site=ehost-live|title = Chicano Studies Examined|last = Gonzalez|first = Phillip B.|date = 2012|journal = Journal of American Ethnic History|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 12 May 2015|subscription = yes|volume = 31|issue = 4|pages = 69–74|issn = 0278-5927}}</ref> His co-founder was Nick. C. Vaca.<ref name=":8" /> Many of the ideas surrounding the formation of later Chicano studies programs stemmed from this publication.<ref name=":7" /> One major idea that was put forth in ''El Grito'' by its editors was that Mexican Americans, in contrast to other ethnic groups, "have retained their distinct identity and refused to disappear into The Great American Melting Pot."<ref name=":8" /> The consequence of this, said the editors, was that Mexican Americans were kept in an economically and politically impoverished state.<ref name=":8" /> Also in 1967, Ralph Guzmán, a political scientist was hired by [[CSULA|Los Angeles State College]] to conduct a study which would lay the foundation for the creation of a national center for Mexican American studies at [[CSULA|California State College, Los Angeles (CSCLA)]].<ref name=":8" /> Both Mexican American and Black Student Unions pressed CSCLA to have ethnic studies classes at this time.<ref name=":8" />
The [[Plan de Santa Barbara]] is generally considered to be the manifesto of Chicano studies.<ref name=":11" /> Drafted in 1969 at the [[University of California, Santa Barbara]], the plan emphasizes the need for education, and especially higher education to enact Chicano community empowerment.<ref name=":0" /> The Plan helped to "establish Chicano studies as an entity incorporated into the structures of academia."<ref name=":0" /> However, while the Plan articulated a need for education, it did not specify how to create a program of study.<ref name=":11" /> The Plan did, however, lead to the creation of the Chicano Studies Institute in 1969.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://oru.research.ucsb.edu/csi/?page_id=6|title = About the Institute|date = |accessdate = 14 May 2015|website = Chicano Studies Institute|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Another important document in Chicano studies was also produced in 1969. In March of that year, the Chicano Youth Conference held in [[Denver]] produced a plan written by Chicano poet, [[Alurista]].<ref name=":8" /> It was called ''[[Plan Espiritual de Aztlán|El Plan Espiritual de Aztlán]]'' (The Spiritual Plan of Aztlán) and it contains a concept of "ethnic nationalism and self-determination."<ref name=":8" /> The idea of the mythic homeland of the Aztec people, [[Aztlán]], is one that unifies the United States and Mexico and correspondingly, united Mexican Americans with a sense of nationalism.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|url = http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/arizona_quarterly_a_journal_of_american_literature_culture_and_theory/v058/58.1.aranda.pdf|title = Making the Case for New Chicano/a Studies: Recovering Our Alienated Selves|last = Aranda Jr.|first = Jose F.|date = 2002|journal = Arizona Quarterly|doi = 10.1353/arq.2002.0011|pmid = |access-date = 14 May 2015|pages = 127–158|subscription = yes|volume = 58|issue = 1}}</ref>
In 1970, a major Chicano journal began to be published at the [[University of California, Los Angeles]] (UCLA).<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|url = http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/american_quarterly/v054/54.4pulido.html|title = In the Spirit of Ernesto Galarza: Recent Publications in Chicano Studies|last = Pulido|first = Alberto Lopez|date = 2002|journal = American Quarterly|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 14 May 2015|subscription = yes|volume = 54|issue = 4|pages = 719–729}}</ref> The journal was called ''Aztlán: A Journal of Chicano Studies'' and it was created at first by the students.<ref name=":9" /> The journal, ''Aztlán'', had a big influence on the discourse surrounding Chicano studies and helped "establish and legitimize" the subject in colleges and universities.<ref name=":9" /> The name of the journal came directly from ''El Plan Espiritual de Aztlán'' and under the direction of the historian Juan Gomez-Quiñones, the journal supported and sustained a culture of activism.<ref name=":10" /> Chicano scholars in 1970 also wrote papers for the Chicano Studies Institute which were later published in the journal, ''Epoca''.<ref name=":11" /> These papers addressed topics such as Chicano curriculum, goals of the educational program and how to achieve academic recognition.<ref name=":11" />
As Chicano studies programs began to be implemented at universities, it was necessary to provide infrastructure and support. In 1973, the [[University of California, Berkeley]] recognized the need to provide quality library materials to support the Chicano studies programs.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://eric.ed.gov/?id=ED164147|title = Providing Library Services for the Chicano Studies Program at the University of California, Berkeley|date = 1973|accessdate = 12 May 2015|website = ERIC|publisher = U.S. Department of Education|last = Padilla|first = Raymond V.}}</ref> Chicano scholars also recognized the need to have a "Chicano-controlled academic" space.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Chicano Studies: The Genesis of a Discipline|last = Soldatenko|first = Michael|publisher = University of Arizona Press|year = 2012|isbn = 9780816599530|location = Tucson, Arizona|pages = 94–129|url = http://muse.jhu.edu/books/9780816599530/9780816599530-9.pdf|chapter = Chicano Studies as an Academic Discipline, 1975-1982|access-date = 14 May 2015}}</ref> Researchers began to study the impact that these new programs had on students, finding that Mexican-American students responded positively to Chicano studies and also to bilingual classes.<ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://eric.ed.gov/?id=ED118160|title = Chicano Studies and Self-Concept: Implications for the Community Colleges|date = 1975|accessdate = 12 May 2015|website = ERIC|publisher = U.S. Department of Education|last = Gonzalez|first = Jess}}</ref> Many scholars felt that the philosophy of education in the United States at the time was "inconsistent with the values of the Chicano movement" and that Chicano studies needed to create tools for students to use in the real world and also a new type of research to solve problems.<ref name=":11" /> It was also important to find ways to recruit Chicano teachers and administration within the schools to support students and research.<ref name=":11" /> Further support for Chicano studies came in the form of the [[National Association of Chicana and Chicano Studies|National Association for Chicana and Chicano Studies]] (NACCS) which was created in 1972 in [[San Antonio|San Antonio, Texas]].<ref name=":12">{{Cite web|url = http://www.naccs.org/naccs/History.asp|title = History of NACCS|date = |accessdate = 14 May 2015|website = National Association for Chicana and Chicano Studies|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The NACCS allows scholars in Chicano studies to exchange ideas, share research, communicate and it also has an annual conference.<ref name=":12" /> The conferences were important to help bring together scholars and legitimize Chicano studies, since other disciplines have similar annual conferences.<ref name=":11" />
By 1975, many Chicano studies programs were in place at major universities.<ref name=":11" />
The ten years between 1977 and 1987 saw "tremendous changes in the foundations of Chicano/a studies."<ref name=":10" /> During this period, Chicano studies began to include more diverse voices that better represented women, homosexuality and other under-represented groups under the umbrella of "Chicano" while also acknowledging the many differences within the group.<ref name=":10" /> In 1981, the Mexican American Studies and Research Center (MASRC) at the University of Arizona was established. MASRC focused on contemporary applied public policy research on Mexican Americans. MASRC became a department in 2009. As the [https://web.archive.org/web/20160402085833/http://mas.arizona.edu/ Mexican American Studies Department], it continued public policy research and teaching to addressing issues of concern to Mexican American communities. It currently offers bachelor's degrees, master's degrees, and in 2011, began offering a Ph.D. degree in Mexican American Studies. The idea of the "borderland" or [[nepantla]] grew stronger than the idea of Aztlán by the 1980s and Chicanaos celebrated the many different (often conflicting) aspects of themselves.<ref name=":10" /> ''[[Borderlands/La Frontera: The New Mestiza]]'' (1987) by [[Gloria E. Anzaldúa|Gloria Anzaldúa]] both grew out of and signifies this change.<ref name=":10" /> Chicano studies became less about nationalism, and more about belonging to a group and contributing to "something greater."<ref name=":10" /> This shift helped reshape the mission of Chicano studies and gave it "new life" and "new authority."<ref name=":10" />
The 1980s saw more Chicano Studies programs integrated into institutions of higher learning while it also created a "canonical approach" to its studies and "gatekeeping procedures" to evaluate promotions and [[tenure]].<ref name=":0" /> In addition, Chicano studies programs helped universities and colleges fulfill [[Affirmative action in the United States|Affirmative Action]] requirements.<ref name=":5" /> During the mid 1990s, however, a study found that most Chicano studies programs were still very non-uniform.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://eric.ed.gov/?id=ED380034|title = Current Mexican-American and Chicano Studies Undergraduate College Programs in the United States|date = 1995|accessdate = 12 May 2015|website = ERIC|publisher = U.S. Department of Education|last = Jaramillo|first = James A.}}</ref> Part of the reason that many Chicano studies programs were not consistent in what was studied is that a core curriculum had not yet been formally published.<ref name=":4" /> The first primer of Chicano studies was published in 1980 by Diego Vigil, called ''From Indians to Chicanos: A Sociocultural History''.<ref name=":4" /> In addition, there was a lack of Chicano faculty with only 1.2% of faculty at U.S. colleges and universities having any "Hispanic" ethnicity at all in 1985.<ref name=":5" /> Many of the faculty teaching Chicano studies didn't feel that their own programs were "qualitatively sound."<ref name=":5" />
== Schools of thought == Chicano studies has two major threads, one is considered pragmatic and the other transformational.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|url = http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/american_literary_history/v025/25.3.perez-torres.html|title = Chicano Studies's Two Paths|last = Pérez-Torres|first = Rafael|date = 2013|journal = American Literary History|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 12 May 2015|volume = 25|issue = 3|subscription = yes|pages = 683–692}}</ref> The pragmatic method involves a more activist and "politicized" approach while the transformational method is more in line with working within the traditions of academia, rather than against it.<ref name=":0" />
==Current Events== [[File:Arizona Ethnic Studies.jpg|alt=Protesters against HB 2281|thumb|350x350px|Protesters are seen in June 2011 in support of the [[Tucson Unified School District]]'s Mexican-American studies program. A new state law effectively ended the program saying it was divisive.]] On May 11, 2010, the Governor of [[Arizona]], [[Jan Brewer]], signed House Bill 2281 (also known as HB 2281) which prohibits a school district or charter school from including in its curriculum courses that #Promote the overthrow of the United States Government #Promote resentment toward any race or class #Advocate ethnic solidarity instead of being individuals #Are designed for a certain ethnicity while still allowing: #Native American classes to comply with federal law #Grouping of classes based on academic performance #Classes about the history of an ethnic group open to all students #Classes discussing controversial history Another provision of the law stated that any school district or charter school breaching its stated provisions would be liable to lose state funding as a public institution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.azleg.gov/legtext/49leg/2r/bills/hb2281s.pdf |title=Arizona House Bill 2281 (2010) |format=PDF |accessdate=October 17, 2011}}</ref>
As a result, the [[Mexican American Studies Department Programs, Tucson Unified School District|Mexican-American studies program]] as taught by Tucson Unified School District (TUSD) came under scrutiny and was found to be in violation of the law by [[Tom Horne]]. However, an independent audit (paid for by the state of Arizona) was conducted, and found the program was not in breach of HB 2281.<ref>{{cite web|title=Racial Lens Used to Cull Curriculum in Arizona|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/19/education/racial-lens-used-to-cull-curriculum-in-arizona.html?_r=2|work=nytimes.com|format=article|accessdate=April 10, 2012}}</ref> With pressure from former Arizona Superintendent [[Tom Horne]], who felt the courses were breaching HB 2281, and after TUSD issued an appeal stating otherwise, Superintendent [[John Huppenthal]] deemed that the course must be disbanded or TUSD would lose funding.<ref name="mex-amer">{{cite news | url=http://www.mexican-american.org/history/2010/arizona/education/chicano-studies-ban.html | title=Arizona Bans Chicano Studies in Public Schools | first=Tito | last=Rodriguez | publisher=Mexican-American.org | date=May 13, 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110427090236/http://www.mexican-american.org/history/2010/arizona/education/chicano-studies-ban.html | archivedate=April 27, 2011 | df= }}</ref> Thus, in January 2012, the TUSD school board came to a 4-1 decision that the program was to be disbanded in lieu of the district losing state funding.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-tucson-school-board-daily-show-20120404,0,5593283.story | title= Mexican American studies: 'Daily Show' Segment Strikes a Nerve | author=Castellanos, Dalina | date=April 4, 2012 | publisher= Los Angeles Times | accessdate=April 10, 2012}}</ref>
A further consequence of HB 2281 was opening the door to challenges and limiting classes teaching Chicano studies not just in Arizona, but across the United States.<ref name=":3" />
== Scholars whose work is associated with Chicano studies == * [[Rodolfo Acuña]] * [[Gloria E. Anzaldúa|Gloria Anzaldúa]] * [[Cecilia Burciaga|Cecilia Preciado de Burciaga]] * [[Luis Leal (writer)|Luis Leal]] * [[Amalia Mesa-Bains]] * Isidro Ortiz * [[Jacinto Quirarte]] * [[María Guillermina Valdes Villalva]] * [[Refugio I Rochin (Founder Smithsonian Latino Center)]] * Felipe de Ortego y Gasca (Founding Director Chicano Studies, University of Texas—El Paso, 1970)

[[File:Church of Christ icon.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Medieval]] Russian [[icon]] depicting the ''[[Life of Christ in art|Life of Christ]]'']] A '''chronology of Jesus''' aims to establish a [[timeline]] for the events of the life of [[Jesus]]. Scholars have correlated [[Jewish]] and [[Greco-Roman]] documents and astronomical calendars with the [[New Testament]] accounts to estimate dates for the major events in Jesus's life. Two main approaches have been used to estimate the year of the [[Nativity of Jesus|birth of Jesus]]: one based on the accounts in the [[Gospels]] of his birth with reference to [[Herod the Great|King Herod's]] reign, and the other by subtracting his stated age of "about 30 years" when he began preaching. Most scholars, on this basis, assume a date of birth between 6 and 4 BC.[[John P. Meier]] (1991). ''A Marginal Jew: Rethinking the Historical Jesus'', v. 1; [[John P. Meier#A Marginal Jew: Rethinking the Historical Jesus|''The Roots of the Problem and the Person'']], ch. 11, ... "A Chronology of Jesus Life," pp. 373–433. [[Anchor Bible Series|Anchor Bible Reference Library]].{{Cite journal | first = | last = [[James Dunn (theologian)|Dunn, James D.G.]] | title = Jesus Remembered | publisher = Eerdmans Publishing | year = 2003 | page = 324}}[[D. A. Carson]], [[Douglas J. Moo]] & [[Leon Morris]]. (1992). ''An Introduction to the New Testament'', 54, 56. Grand Rapids, MI: Zondervan Publishing House.[[Michael Grant (author)|Michael Grant]]. (1977). ''Jesus: An Historian's Review of the Gospels'', p. 71. Scribner's.[[Ben Witherington III]]. (1998). "Primary Sources". ''Christian History'', ''17'' (3), 12–20. Three details have been used to estimate the year when [[Ministry of Jesus|Jesus began preaching]]: a mention of his age of "about 30 years" during "the fifteenth year" of the reign of [[Tiberius Caesar]], another relating to the date of the building of the [[Herod's Temple|Temple in Jerusalem]], and yet another concerning the [[death of John the Baptist]].Eerdman Publishing. (2000). ''Eerdman’s Dictionary of the Bible'', page 249. Amsterdam University Press. {{ISBN|90-5356-503-5}}.Craig A. Evans. (2003). ''The Bible Knowledge Background Commentary: Matthew-Luke'', volume 1, pages 67-69 {{ISBN|0-7814-3868-3}}.[[Paul L. Maier]]. "The Date of the Nativity and Chronology of Jesus" [In] Jerry Vardaman, Edwin M. Yamauchi. (1989). ''Chronos, kairos, Christos: nativity and chronological studies'', pages 113-129. {{ISBN|0-931464-50-1}}.Craig Evans. (2006). Josephus on John the Baptist [In] Amy-Jill Levine et al.[Eds]. (2006). ''The Historical Jesus in Context'', pages 55-58. Princeton University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-691-00992-6}}. [https://books.google.com/books?id=HIp_0N3uPPcC&pg=PA56&dq=%22Mark+6:17%22+death+baptist+josephus&hl=en&ei=hTubTpKeHcX54QTn1YHBAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Mark%206%3A17%22%20death%20baptist%20josephus&f=false]Florence Morgan Gillman. (2003). ''Herodias: at home in that fox's den'', pages 25-30. {{ISBN|0-8146-5108-9}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=rFRFe8QdO1gC&pg=PA26&dq=herodias+herod+antipas&hl=en&ei=fECbTq31JvDc4QT8ubiZBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CEQQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=herodias%20herod%20antipas&f=false]Geoffrey W. Bromiley. (1982). ''International Standard Bible Encyclopedia'', volume E-J, pages 694-695. {{ISBN|0-8028-3782-4}}. [https://books.google.com/books?id=yklDk6Vv0l4C&pg=PA695&dq=herodias+john+baptist&hl=en&ei=PJacToTRNK-L4gThwKGkCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=herodias%20john%20baptist&f=false] Hence, scholars estimate that Jesus began preaching and gathering followers around AD 28–29. According to the three [[synoptic gospel]]s Jesus continued preaching for at least one year, and according to [[John the Evangelist]] for three years.''The Riddles of the Fourth Gospel: An Introduction to John'' by Paul N. Anderson 2011 {{ISBN|0-8006-0427-X}} page 200''Herod the Great'' by Jerry Knoblet 2005 {{ISBN|0-7618-3087-1}} pages 183–184J. Dwight Pentecost. (1981) ''The Words and Works of Jesus Christ: A Study of the Life of Christ'', pages 577–578. Zondervan. Five methods have been used to estimate the date of the [[crucifixion of Jesus]]. One uses non-Christian sources such as [[Josephus]] and [[Tacitus]].{{cite book |last=Funk |first=Robert W. |author2=[[Jesus Seminar]] |authorlink=Robert W. Funk| title=The acts of Jesus: the search for the authentic deeds of Jesus |year=1998 |publisher=Harper |location=San Francisco}}Paul William Meyer, John T. Carroll. (2004). ''The Word in this world'', page 112. {{ISBN|0-664-22701-5}}. Another works backwards from the historically well-established trial of the [[Apostle Paul]] by the [[Lucius Junius Gallio Annaeanus|Roman proconsul Gallio]] in Corinth in AD 51/52 to estimate the date of [[Conversion of Paul the Apostle|Paul's conversion]]. Both methods result in AD 36 as an upper bound to the crucifixion.Andreas J. Köstenberger, L. Scott Kellum. (2009). ''The Cradle, the Cross, and the Crown: An Introduction to the New Testament'', pages 77-79. {{ISBN|978-0-8054-4365-3}}.[[Rainer Riesner]]. (1997). ''Paul's early period: chronology, mission strategy, theology'' pages 19-27. {{ISBN|978-0-8028-4166-7}}. Page 27 has a table of various scholarly estimates. Recent astronomical research uses the contrast between the synoptic date of Jesus' last Passover on the one hand with John's date of the subsequent "Jewish Passover" on the other hand, to propose Jesus' Last Supper to have been on Wednesday, 1 April AD 33 and the crucifixion on Friday 3 April AD 33. ==Context and overview== [[File:Josephus Antiquitates Iudaice.jpg|thumb|left|180px|''[[Antiquities of the Jews]]'' by [[Flavius Josephus|Josephus]], a source for the chronology of Jesus.]]The Christian gospels do not claim to provide an exhaustive list of the events in the life of Jesus{{cite book |authorlink= Raymond E. They calculate the death of Jesus as having taken place between AD 30 and 36. == Year of Jesus' birth == {{See also|Nativity of Jesus|Date of birth of Jesus}} The date of birth of Jesus of Nazareth is not stated in the gospels or in any secular text, but most scholars assume a date of birth between 6 BC and 4 BC, but nobody knows the exact date. Two main methods have been used to estimate the year of the [[Nativity of Jesus|birth of Jesus]]: one based on the accounts of his birth in the gospels with reference to [[Herod the Great|King Herod's]] reign, and another based on subtracting his stated age of "about 30 years" from the time when he began preaching ([[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Luke#3:23|Luke 3:23]]) in "the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar" ([[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Luke#3:1|Luke 3:1-2]]): the two methods indicate a date of birth before Herod's death in 4 BC, and a date of birth around 2 BC, respectively. *''New Testament History'' by Richard L. Scarola, "A Chronology of the nativity Era" in ''Chronos, kairos, Christos 2'' by Ray Summers, Jerry Vardaman 1998 {{ISBN|0-86554-582-0}} pages 61–81 ===Other approaches=== The Gospel of John 8:57 mentions in passing an upper limit of 50 for Jesus' age when preaching: ''Then the Jews said to Him: You are not even fifty years old, and you claim to have seen Abraham?'' Fifty years is a round number which emphasises the discrepancy to Jesus's claim he had existed before Abraham, that is, for more than a thousand years.[[Colin Humphreys]], ''The Mystery of the Last Supper'' Cambridge University Press 2011 {{ISBN|978-0-521-73200-0}}, page 72 Some commentators have attempted to establish the date of birth by identifying the [[Star of Bethlehem]] with some known astronomical or astrological phenomenon. For example, astronomer Michael Molnar proposed 17 April 6 BC as the likely date of the Nativity, since that date corresponded to the [[heliacal rising]] and lunar [[occultation]] of [[Jupiter]], while it was [[Apparent retrograde motion#Apparent motion|momentarily stationary]] in the [[Aries (constellation)|constellation of Aries]]. According to Molnar, to knowledgeable astrologers of this time, this highly unusual combination of events would have indicated that a regal personage would be (or had been) born in Judea. Michael R. Molnar, "The Star of Bethlehem: The Legacy of the Magi," Rutgers University Press, 1999. Other research points to a 1991 report from the Royal Astronomical Society, which mentions that Chinese astronomers noted a "comet" that lasted 70 days in the Capricorn region of the sky, in March of 5 BC. Authors Dugard and O'Reilly consider this event as the likely Star of Bethlehem. O'Reilly, Bill, and Dugard, Martin, "Killing Jesus: A History," Henry Holt and Company, 2013, {{ISBN|0805098542}}, page 15. However, there are many possible phenomena and none seems to match the Gospel account exactly.Raymond E. Brown, ''101 Questions and Answers on the Bible'', Paulist Press (2003), page 79. ==Years of preaching== ===Reign of Tiberius and the Gospel of Luke=== [[File:Sapsaphas Madaba.jpg|thumb|Part of the [[Madaba Map]] showing [[Bethabara]] (Βέθαβαρά), calling it the place where John baptised]] One method for the estimation of the date of the beginning of the [[ministry of Jesus]] is based on the Gospel of Luke's specific statement in [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Luke#3:1|Luke 3:1-2]] about the ministry of [[John the Baptist]] which preceded that of Jesus:
Now in the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar, Pontius Pilate being governor of Judaea, and Herod being tetrarch of Galilee, and his brother Philip tetrarch of the region of Ituraea and Trachonitis, and Lysanias tetrarch of Abilene, in the highpriesthood of Annas and Caiaphas, the word of God came unto John the son of Zacharias in the wilderness.
The reign of [[Tiberius Caesar]] began on the death of his predecessor [[Augustus Caesar]] in September AD 14, implying that the ministry of John the Baptist began in late AD 28 or early AD 29.Andreas J. Köstenberger, L. Scott Kellum, Charles L Quarles, ''The Cradle, the Cross, and the Crown'' (B&H Publishing, 2009), page 139-140.''Luke 1-5: New Testament Commentary'' by John MacArthur 2009 {{ISBN|0-8024-0871-0}} page 201 Riesner's alternative suggestion is that John the Baptist began his ministry in AD 26 or 27, because Tiberius ruled together with Augustus for two years before becoming the sole ruler. If so, the fifteenth year of Tiberius' reign would be counted from AD 12. Riesner's suggestion is however considered less likely, as all the major Roman historians who calculate the years of Tiberius' rule - namely Tacitus, Suetonius and Cassius Dio - count from AD 14 - the year of Augustus' death. In addition, coin evidence shows that Tiberius started to reign in AD 14.[[Colin Humphreys]], ''The Mystery of the Last Supper'' Cambridge University Press 2011 {{ISBN|978-0-521-73200-0}}, page 64 The New Testament presents [[John the Baptist]] as the precursor to Jesus and the [[Baptism of Jesus]] as marking the beginning of Jesus' ministry.''Jesus and the Gospels: An Introduction and Survey'' by Craig L. Blomberg 2009 {{ISBN|0-8054-4482-3}} page 224-229''Christianity: an introduction'' by Alister E. McGrath 2006 {{ISBN|978-1-4051-0901-7}} pages 16-22 In his sermon in [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Acts#10:37|Acts 10:37-38]], delivered in the house of [[Cornelius the Centurion|Cornelius]] the centurion, [[Apostle Peter]] refers to what had happened "throughout all Judaea, beginning from Galilee, after the baptism which John preached" and that Jesus had then gone about "doing good".''Who is Jesus?: an introduction to Christology'' by Thomas P. Rausch 2003 {{ISBN|978-0-8146-5078-3}} page Jesus' baptism account is followed directly by his [[Temptation of Christ|40 day fast and ordeal]]. ===The Temple in Jerusalem and the Gospel of John=== [[File:Jerusalem Modell BW 3.JPG|right|thumb|[[Herod's Temple]], referred to in [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/John#2:13|John 2:13]], as imagined in the [[Holyland Model of Jerusalem]]. It is currently situated adjacent to the [[Shrine of the Book]] exhibit at the [[Israel Museum]], Jerusalem.]] Another method for estimating the start of the ministry of Jesus without reliance on the [[Synoptic gospels]] is to relate the account in the [[Gospel of John]] about the visit of Jesus to [[Herod's Temple]] in Jerusalem with historical data about the construction of the Temple. [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/John#2:13|John 2:13]] says that Jesus went to the [[Herod's Temple|Temple in Jerusalem]] around the start of his ministry and in [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/John#2:20|John 2:20]] Jesus is told: "This temple has been under construction for forty-six years, and will you raise it up in three days?". Herod's Temple in Jerusalem was an extensive and long term construction on the [[Temple Mount]], which was never fully completed even by the time it was destroyed by the Romans in AD 70.''The biblical engineer: how the temple in Jerusalem was built'' by Max Schwartz 2002 {{ISBN|0-88125-710-9}} pages xixx-xx Having built entire cities such as [[Caesarea Maritima]], Herod saw the construction of the Temple as a key, colossal monument.''The Temple of Jerusalem: past, present, and future'' by John M. Lundquist 2007 {{ISBN|0-275-98339-0}} pages101-103 [https://books.google.com/books?id=R9VeCEwbNvsC&pg=PA102&dq=%22john+2:20%22+temple&hl=en&ei=kpydTvvXB-qK4gSg2NHPCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CFYQ6AEwCTgU#v=onepage&q=%22john%202%3A20%22%20temple&f=false] The dedication of the initial temple (sometimes called the inner Temple) followed a 17 or 18 month construction period, just after the visit of [[Augustus]] to Syria.''The building program of Herod the Great'' by Duane W. Roller 1998 University of California Press {{ISBN|0-520-20934-6}} pages 67-71 [https://books.google.com/books?id=2ZsB1yQOmyEC&pg=PA258&dq=herod+temple+construction&hl=en&ei=DredTu3cIqT64QSitp2nCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CD8Q6AEwAzge#v=onepage&q=temple%20construction&f=false] [[Josephus]] ([[wikisource:The Antiquities of the Jews/Book XV|Ant 15.11.1]]) states that the temple's reconstruction was started by Herod in the 18th year of his reign.''Encyclopedia of the historical Jesus'' by Craig A. Evans 2008 {{ISBN|0-415-97569-7}} page 115 But there is some uncertainty about how Josephus referred to and computed dates, which event marked the start of Herod's reign, and whether the initial date should refer to the inner Temple, or the subsequent construction. Hence various scholars arrive at slightly different dates for the exact date of the start of the Temple construction, varying by a few years in their final estimation of the date of the Temple visit.''The Cradle, the Cross, and the Crown: An Introduction to the New Testament'' by Andreas J. Köstenberger, L. Scott Kellum 2009 {{ISBN|978-0-8054-4365-3}} pages 140-141 Given that it took 46 years of construction, the best scholarly estimate for when Jesus preached is around the year AD 29.Andreas J. Köstenberger, John (Baker Academic, 2004), page 110.''Jesus in Johannine tradition'' by Robert Tomson Fortna, Tom Thatcher 2001 {{ISBN|978-0-664-22219-2}} page 77 ===Josephus' reference to John the Baptist=== Both the gospels and first-century historian [[Flavius Josephus]], in his work [[Antiquities of the Jews]],''The new complete works of Josephus by Flavius Josephus'', William Whiston, Paul L. Maier {{ISBN|0-8254-2924-2}} refer to [[Herod Antipas]] killing [[John the Baptist]], and to the marriage of Herod and [[Herodias]], establishing two key connections between Josephus and the biblical episodes. Josephus refers to the imprisonment and execution of John the Baptist by Herod Antipas and that Herodias left her husband to marry Herod Antipas, in defiance of Jewish law.[[wikisource:The Antiquities of the Jews/Book XVIII#Chapter 5|Ant 18.5.2-4]] Josephus and the gospels differ, however, on the details and motives, e.g. whether the execution was a consequence of the marriage of Herod Antipas and Herodias (as indicated in [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Matthew#14:4|Matthew 14:4]], [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Mark#6:18|Mark 6:18]]), or a pre-emptive measure by Herod which possibly took place before the marriage to quell a possible uprising based on the remarks of John, as Josephus suggests in [[wikisource:The Antiquities of the Jews/Book XVIII#Chapter 5|Ant 18.5.2]].''Jesus in history, thought, and culture: an encyclopedia, Volume 1'' by James Leslie Houlden 2003 {{ISBN|1-57607-856-6}} pages 508-509 [https://books.google.com/books?id=17kzgBusXZIC&pg=PA508&dq=baptist+josephus+antipas+jesus&hl=en&ei=5kmbTvPYB9TP4QSuzIDjAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&sqi=2&ved=0CEAQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=baptist%20herodias%20josephus%20antipas%20jesus&f=false]''Women in scripture'' by [[Carol Meyers]], Toni Craven and Ross Shepard Kraemer 2001 {{ISBN|0-8028-4962-8}} pages 92-93 [https://books.google.com/books?id=MFbHT73BxpAC&pg=PA93&dq=herodias+herod&hl=en&ei=FJmcToy0M4abOtTmzIYJ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=herodias%20herod&f=false]''Herod Antipas in Galilee: The Literary and Archaeological Sources'' by Morten H. Jensen 2010 {{ISBN|978-3-16-150362-7}} pages 42-43 [https://books.google.com/books?id=I7fAyl2aG-gC&pg=PA43&dq=herodias+herod&hl=en&ei=FJmcToy0M4abOtTmzIYJ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=herodias%20herod&f=false]''The Emergence of Christianity: Classical Traditions in Contemporary Perspective'' by Cynthia White 2010 {{ISBN|0-8006-9747-2}} page 48 [[File:Baptistry (Castiglione Olona) 003.jpg|thumb|[[John the Baptist|The Baptist]] scolds [[Herod Antipas|Herod]]. Fresco by [[Masolino da Panicale|Masolino]], 1435]] The exact year of the marriage of [[Herod Antipas]] and [[Herodias]] is subject to debate among scholars. While some scholars place the year of the marriage in the range AD 27-31, others have approximated a date as late as AD 35, although such a late date has much less support. In his analysis of Herod's life, [[Harold Hoehner]] estimates that John the Baptist's imprisonment probably occurred around AD 30-31.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=oO0upEG0g7kC&pg=PA131&dq=herodias+herod+antipas#v=onepage&q=herodias%20herod%20antipas&f=false |title=''Herod Antipas'' by Harold W. Josephus stated ([[wikisource:The Antiquities of the Jews/Book XVIII#Chapter 5|Ant 18.5.2]]) that the AD 36 defeat of Herod Antipas in the conflicts with [[Aretas IV Philopatris|Aretas IV]] of [[Nabatea]] was widely considered by the Jews of the time as misfortune brought about by Herod's unjust execution of John the Baptist.''The relationship between John the Baptist and Jesus of Nazareth'' by Daniel S. Dapaah 2005 {{ISBN|0-7618-3109-6}} page 48 [https://books.google.com/books?id=S0P18O3fGR4C&pg=PA48&dq=baptist+josephus+antipas+jesus&hl=en&ei=5kmbTvPYB9TP4QSuzIDjAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&sqi=2&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=baptist%20josephus%20antipas%20jesus&f=false] Given that John the Baptist was executed before the defeat of Herod by Aretas, and based on the scholarly estimates for the approximate date of the marriage of Herod Antipas and Herodias, the last part of the ministry of John the Baptist and hence parts of the ministry of Jesus fall within the historical time span of AD 28-35, with the later year 35 having the least support among scholars.''Herod Antipas'' by Harold W.
